poem:
Title: The Motion Picture Dance

No Barbenheimer this season,
nor any muscular blockbusters -
yet the silver screen thrums with a softer
pulsation. 

The arthouse breathes subtitled whispers,
a ballet of foreign tongues dance;
Young eyes follow, enlivened,
drawn into the drama of others. 

Beneath a summer's dome,
filmgoing no longer craves heavier yields,
but delights in a lighter harvest,
of meaning and nuance sown.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "‘We’re excited’: arthouse hits draw young UK filmgoers to a summer of subtitles This time last summer, British cinemas were holding their collective breath, looking forward to the biggest box office weekend of the year. “Barbenheimer” came to the rescue, with the doubleheader of blockbusters jointly chalking up an initial total of £30m when released in mid-July. This summer is a different story. There may be no lucrative Barbie or Oppenheimer at hand, but the". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
